metadata.title: Dynamics of an imprecise stochastic LotkaVolterra food chain chemostat model with Lévy jumps

abstract.text: Population dynamics are often affected by sudden environmental perturbations. Parameters of stochastic models are often imprecise due to various uncertainties. In this paper, we formulate a stochastic LotkaVolterra food chain chemostat model that includes Lévy jumps and interval parameters. Firstly, we prove the existence and uniqueness of the positive solution. Moreover, the threshold between extinction and persistence in the mean of the microorganism is obtained. Finally, some simulations are carried out to demonstrate our theoretical results.

body_text.text: 2 Imprecise stochastic LotkaVolterra food chain chemostat model
body_text.section: Fei Sun

body_text.text: In this section, we introduce the imprecise stochastic LotkaVolterra food chain chemostat model. Let S(t), x(t) and y(t) denote the concentrations of nutrient, prey and predator at time t, respectively. Then a stochastic LotkaVolterra food chain chemostat model takes the following form [19] .
body_text.section: Fei Sun

body_text.text: dy(t) = [m 2 x(t)y(t) − Dy(t)]dt + σ 3 y(t)dB 3 (t) + Y γ 3 y(t − ) N (dt, du).
body_text.section: Fei Sun

body_text.text: where S 0 is the original input concentration of nutrient and D is the input rate from the feed vessel to the culture vessel, as well as the washout rate from the culture vessel to the receptacle. δ 1 and δ 2 are the yield constants for prey growth on nutrient and predator growth on prey, respectively. B i (t), i = 1, 2, 3 are standard Brownian motions. σ 2 i represent the intensities of B i (t). λ is the characteristic measure of N which is defined on a finite measurable subset Y of (0, +∞) with λ(Y) < ∞. γ i (u) : Y × Ω → R are the bounded and continuous functions satisfying γ i (u) > −1, i = 1, 2, 3. The S(t − ), x(t − ) and y(t − ) are the left limits of S(t), x(t) and y(t), respectively. N denotes the compensated random measure defined by N (dt, du) = N (dt, du)λ(du)dt. We assume B i and N are independent throughout the paper and denote

body_text.section: Existence and uniqueness of positive solution of system (2.3)

body_text.text: Theorem 31 Let Assumptions (H1) and (H2) hold. Then for any given initial value (S(0), x(0), y(0)) ∈ R 3 + , system (2.3) has a unique solution (S(t), x(t), y(t)) ∈ R 3 + for all t ≥ 0 almost surely (a.s.).
body_text.section: Existence and uniqueness of positive solution of system (2.3)

body_text.text: Proof. Because the coefficients of system (2.3) are local Lipschitz continuous (Mao [17] ), for any given initial value (S(0), x(0), y(0)) ∈ R 3 + , there is a unique local solution (S(t), x(t), y(t)) on t ∈ [0, τ e ), where τ e is the explosion time (see Mao [17] ). In order to show that the local solution is global, we only need to prove that τ e = ∞ a.s. In this context, choosing a sufficiently large number k 0 ≥ 1 such that (S(0), x(0), y(0)) lie within the interval [ 1 k 0 , k 0 ]. For each integer k ≥ k 0 , we define the stopping time as

body_text.text: When studying dynamical models, two of the most interesting issues are persistence and extinction. In this section, we discuss the extinction of microorganisms in system (2.3) and leave its persistence to the next section.
body_text.section: Extinction

body_text.text: Before we state the main results of this section, several lemmas (gao et al. [19] ) should be recalled without the proofs and relevant explanations.
